questions.text: Choose the correct options from the given statements of the enteric nervous system? Vagus is the only afferent from gut Functions independent of brain and Spinal cord Myenteric plexus in the lamina propria Exclusively under the influence of nerves Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 Among the given options, the correct statement is that the enteric nervous system functions independent of the brain and spinal cord and this is the reason it is called the mini brain of the gut.

Highyeild:

Enteric nervous system includes myenteric plexus (lie between longitudinal and circular layers of intestinal smooth muscle) and submucosal nerve plexus. The neurons of these plexuses are small interneurons that connect afferent neurons and efferent neurons to smooth muscles, secretory cells and epithelial cells , and they form the anatomical basis of local GI reflexes. Therefore, the reflex arc for local GI reflexes is located within the GI tract. Hence, ENS is capable of coordinating GI activity in the absence of external innervation. Many afferent sensory nerve fibers innervate the gut. Some of the nerve fibers have their cell bodies in the enteric nervous system, and some have them in the dorsal root ganglia of the spinal cord They are not exclusively under influence of nerves, but also under control of hormones Parasympathetic and sympathetic connects enteric nervous system to Autonomic nervous system

questions.text: LMN lesions are associated with? Decrease in muscle tone Spastic paralysis Babinski positive Fasciculations Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,4 Hypotonia and fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesion, while the others are seen in upper motor neuron lesion

Highyeild:

Feature Upper Motor Neuron Lesion Lower Motor Neuron Lesion Site of the lesion ● Cerebral hemispheres, cerebellum, brainstem, spinal cord ● Anterior horn cell, nerve roots, peripheral nerves. ● neuromuscular junction, muscles Muscle weakness ● Quadriplegia, hemiplegia, diplegia, paraplegia ● Proximal (myopathy) ● Distal (neuropathy) Muscle tone ● Spasticity, rigidity ● Hypotonia Fasciculations ● Absent ● Present (particularly tongue) Tendon reflexes ● Hyperreflexia ● Hypo/areflexia Abdominal reflexes ● Absent (depending on the involved spinal level) ● Present Sensory loss ● Cortical sensations ● Peripheral sensations Electromyography (EMG) ● Normal nerve conduction ● Decreased interference pattern and firing rate ● Abnormal nerve conduction ● Large motor units ● Fasciculations and fibrillations

questions.text: What contributes to the latent period of muscle twitch? Neuromuscular transmission Excitation contraction coupling Reuptake of calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum Transmission impulse from nerve Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,4 Reuptake of calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum causes relaxation

Highyeild:

Twitch: mechanical response of single muscle fibre to an action potential consisting of a phase of contraction followed by a relaxation phase (A) Action potential recorded from skeletal muscle fiber: (B) Simultaneous recording of contractile response on the same timescale: (LP: Latent period; CT: Contraction time; RT: Relaxation time). Contractile response begins about 2 ms after onset of action potential. This delay is known as latent period and it occurs due to time taken for:

questions.text: Which of these systems do not require ATP? Paracellular Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Antiport (Na/K ATPase) Symport Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3 Paracellular transport, simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion are examples of passive transport and ATP is not required in these processes

Highyeild:

In passive transport, the substances pass through membrane from both the sides, however net movement occurs down the electrochemical gradient They do not require utilization of ATP (metabolic energy) Examples include Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, osmosis, filtration, bulk flow and solvent drug

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Symport and antiport are active transport processes and ATP is required in this (hydrolysis of ATP occurs)

Table:

#MANTRA Types Of Transport Processes And Difference Between Active And Passive Transport 1. Passive transports Solvent drag Bulk flow Filtration Osmosis Facilitated diffusion Simple diffusion 2. Active transports Secondary active transport Primary active transport 3. Vesicular transports Endocytosis Exocytosis 4. Transport across epithelia Transcellular transport Paracellular transport Active transport Passive transport 1. Nature of transport Against electrochemical gradient Along the gradient 2. Utilization of energy ATP hydrolysis occurs Not needed 3. Saturation kinetics Is a feature May not be present

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in decompression sickness?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemodilution Of the options given, hemodilution is not seen in decompression sickness, whereas hemoconcentration is seen ( due to extravasation of plasma, as a result of capillary leak).

Highyeild:

Decompression sickness (Caissons disease) occurs when the subjects exposed to high atmospheric pressures are suddenly brought to low atmospheric pressure (eg., deep sea divers) Important factor contributing to severity of decompression sickness is not absolute decrease, but the percentage decrease in pressure Symptoms are caused by gas bubbles blocking many blood vessels in different tissues In most people, symptoms are pain in the joints and muscles of the legs and arms, affecting 85% to 90% of persons who experience decompression sickness. The joint pain accounts for the term “bends” that is often applied In 5% to 10% of people, nervous system symptoms occur, ranging from dizziness in about 5% to paralysis or collapse and unconsciousness in as many as 3%. The paralysis may be temporary, but in some cases, damage is permanent About 2% of people experience “the chokes,” caused by massive numbers of microbubbles plugging the capillaries of the lungs. This condition is characterized by serious shortness of breath, often followed by severe pulmonary edema and, occasionally, death It is prevented by gradual ascent to sea level and the reduction pressure should not exceed 50% Treatment As soon as symptoms develop, subject is recompressed immediately in pressurized cabin Quick recompression should be followed by slow decompression Hyperbaric oxygen is helpful

questions.text: Which receptor contributes to static 2 point discrimination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Merkel cell Static 2 point discrimination is by slowly adaptive merkel cell

Highyeild:

Cutaneous Mechanoreceptors Touch and pressure are sensed by four types of mechanoreceptors Sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated A𝛂 and A𝛃 fibres whose conduction velocities ranges from ~70-120 to ~40-75 m/s, respectively Meissner corpuscles Dendritic encapsulated in connective tissue beneath epidermis of glabrous skin and respond to slow vibration Merkel cells Expanded dendritic endings in epidermis of glabrous skin that respond to sustained pressure and touch Ruffini corpuscles Enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in dermis of glabrous and hairy skin Respond to stretch and fluttering vibration Pacinian corpuscles Largest , 2mm long and 1mm in diameter Dermis of glabrous and hairy skin Nerve endings encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give an onion-like appearance Respond to fast vibration and deep pressure

Extraedge:

Physiological classification and functions of nerve fibres

Table:

#MANTRA Rapidly Adapting Receptors Slowly Adapting Receptors ● MEISSNER CORPUSCLES ○ Tapping and slow vibrations ● PACINIAN CORPUSCLES ○ Fast vibration and deep pressure ● MERKEL CELLS ○ Sustained pressure and touch ○ Used in reading Braille ● RUFFINI ENDINGS ○ Skin stretch and vibration ● MUSCLE SPINDLES ● NOCICEPTORS

questions.text: Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?

options.label: A
options.text: A- Z line B- A band C-I band D- H band

options.label: B
options.text: A-Z line B-I band C- A band D- H band

options.label: C
options.text: A-M line B-I band C-H band D-I band

options.label: D
options.text: A-M line B- I band C- A band D- H band

questions.correct_answer: B. A-Z line B-I band C- A band D- H band
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-Z line B-I band C- A band D- H band

Highyeild:

The sarcomere is defined as spanning from Z-line to Z-line , only a few micrometers long, and consists of an A band containing myosin (“thick” ) filaments, which is flanked by two half I-bands made up of actin (“thin”) filaments. This A band is the central region of the sarcomere, composed primarily of myosin filaments, the force-generating motor protein of skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle The H-band is an area of the A-band in which the thick filaments are the only longitudinal elements. The M-band is the dense, very central region of the H-band that contains cross-links that connect the thick filaments into a network.

Table:

#MANTRA Structure Of Sarcomere:

questions.text: The O₂ saturation with respect to PO₂ is marked as A. What happens to the Oxygen Hb dissociation curve upon transfusion of stored RBC?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B In stored blood, 2,3-DPG concentration decreases and on transfusion they decrease the oxygen transport resulting in left shift ( curve B) The effect is less when blood is stored in acid citrate dextrose solution

Highyeild:

Factors That Affect 2,3-Dpg In Red Cells pH: Acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis and, therefore, decreases 2,3-DPG concentration. Type of Hb: The γ chains of fetal Hb have less avidity for 2,3-DPG than β chains of adult Hb. Therefore, fetal Hb has higher oxygen affinity. This provides an advantage to the fetus to extract oxygen from maternal blood in the placenta . Fetal Hb shifts Oxy-Hb dissociation curve to left Hormones: Growth hormone, thyroxine and testosterone stimulate the synthesis of 2,3-DPG . Altitude: At high altitude, 2,3-DPG concentration increases substantially in red cells. This increases the availability of oxygen to the tissues. PO2: Hypoxia increases 2,3-DPG production . Procedure of storage of blood: The 2,3-DPG concentration in red cells of blood stored in the blood bank decreases. Therefore, transfusion of stored blood decreases oxygen transport, especially when transfused into hypoxic patients.

Table:

#MANTRA Oxygen Dissociation Curve: Factors Shifting Curve To Right: Increases P 50 ( decreased affinity of Hb for oxygen) that facilitates oxygen release Increased temperature Decreased pH Increased pCO 2 Increased 2,3-dpg Hypoxia Factors Shifting Curve To Left: Decreases P 50 ( increases affinity of Hb for oxygen ) that facilitates oxygen uptake and prevents oxygen release Decreased temperature Increased pH Decreased PCO 2 Fetal Hb Carbon monoxide

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypoxia Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to changes in PO 2 , PCO 2 and pH in arterial blood The major stimulus for activation is reduced PO 2 ( hypoxia )

Highyeild:

At normal blood pH and PCO2, increase in PO2 above normal range does not have significant effect on breathing, but decrease in PaO2 less than 100 mm of Hg results in progressive increase in the firing rate of afferent nerves that increases ventilation. The response becomes prominent when alveolar PO2 falls below 80 mm Hg. The response is most effective at PO2 less than 60 mm Hg

Extraedge:

Response of peripheral chemoreceptors to oxygen depends on PaO 2 and not on oxygen content In anemia and carbon monoxide poisoning - has little effect on ventilation response curve since they have normal PaO 2

Table:

#MANTRA Role Of Peripheral And Central Chemoreceptors In Ventilation:

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement about Physiological dead space?

options.label: B
options.text: Is lesser than anatomical dead space

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Represents inadequately perfused alveoli Physiological dead space represents inadequately perfused alveoli and not inadequately ventilated alveoli

Highyeild:

Dead space: space within airways that do not allow gas exchange with pulmonary capillary blood to occur. Since it is due to anatomy of airways it is known as Anatomical dead space For each 500 ml of air inhaled, about 150 ml remains in the conducting airways which is not used in gas exchange ( Dead space volume ) Some amount of inspired air in alveoli does not participate in gas exchange the alveoli may have little or no blood supply and the air in alveoli becomes part of wasted air. This volume of air in these alveoli is referred to as Alveolar dead space Physiological dead space = Anatomical dead space + alveolar dead space alveolar dead space is negligible in normal individuals, hence anatomical dead space is almost equal to physiological dead space

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Volume of dead space is usually measured by a single breath technique that uses Bohr’s equation in the form of gas such as CO 2 . Single breath nitrogen test is also used Option: B. Anatomical dead space is almost equal to physiological dead space in normal individuals. In lung diseases, alveolar dead space becomes high, in which physiological dead space is more than anatomical dead space.
